title: R41430
content: Inland waterways, managed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, cover 38 states and handle half of all inland waterway freight. The Corps funds maintenance and construction through appropriations and user fees. Maintenance on the Inland Waterway System is fully funded by the Corps, while new construction costs are shared equally. The Corps and commercial industry share costs for new construction and major rehabilitation on inland waterways. Congress is considering proposals for future financing due to current revenue sources being insufficient. This shortfall limits construction projects, requiring changes to the financing system. The ongoing shortfall in funding for inland waterway construction projects is limiting new developments. Recent proposals suggest changes to the financing system, including increasing fuel taxes and federal shares. Inland waterways have been crucial for commerce since before the nation's founding, with federal support starting in the early 1800s. Inland waterways have been important for commerce since the early 1800s, with federal support increasing after the Supreme Court granted authority over interstate commerce in 1824. While other forms of transportation have reduced reliance on waterways, they still account for 4%-5% of total commercial tonnage shipped annually. In some regions, especially for bulk goods over long distances, waterways remain a significant transportation route, particularly for grain and oilseed exports. In some regions, inland waterways remain important for transporting bulk goods over long distances, including grain, oilseed, coal, petroleum, chemicals, and metals. Despite projections for increased traffic, actual inland waterway traffic has remained relatively flat over the past 20 years. Overall freight tonnage is expected to double in the next 25 years, with inland waterway traffic projected to increase at a slower rate compared to rail and highway shipping. The Department of Transportation projects a 1.2% increase in overall freight tonnage from 1997 to 2007, with inland waterway traffic expected to grow at a slower rate compared to rail and highway shipping. The federal government invests in inland waterways due to their value to the nation, with investments dating back to the early 1800s and funding provided through the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Legislation in the 1970s and 1980s introduced user cost-sharing requirements for some costs, with the Inland Waterways Revenue Act of 1978 and the Water Resources Development Act of 1986 establishing a fuel tax on commercial barges and cost-share requirements for projects. This shifted financial responsibility to commercial operators on the inland waterway system. The acts of 1978 and 1986 established a fuel tax on commercial barges, cost-share requirements for inland waterway projects, and a trust fund to hold revenues for construction investments. Commercial operators on the inland waterway system gained greater financial and decision-making responsibility. The Inland Waterways Revenue Act of 1978 codified the federal policy of taxing fuel on commercial barge traffic and established the Inland Waterways Trust Fund (IWTF). The IWTF was funded by a fuel tax, gradually increasing to $0.10 per gallon in FY1986. WRDA 1986 authorized additional fuel tax increases, rising to $0.20 per gallon in 1994, and laid out a cost-sharing process for inland waterway projects. WRDA 1986 authorized additional fuel tax increases, reaching $0.20 per gallon in 1994. It established a 50/50 cost-sharing process for inland waterway projects, with construction funded by IWTF and Treasury's GR fund. O&M costs remained a federal responsibility. The WRDA 1986 authorized projects funded by the IWTF with 100% federal funding for inland waterway costs, excluding construction and major maintenance. It also established the Inland Waterways Users Board (IWUB) as a federal advisory committee with 11 members. The Inland Waterways Users Board (IWUB) was established by WRDA 1986 as a federal advisory committee with 11 members representing shipping interests on inland waterways. The board meets regularly to make recommendations to the Secretary of the Army and Congress regarding investments in IWTF projects. The IWTF balance has varied significantly between 1986 and 2011, with proposals to increase fees on the user industry to fund operations.
